elements.title: Wizard Step Enclosure as Character Armor
elements.problem: During listing creation, the host is progressively shedding character armor. If each wizard step visually bleeds into the next or feels part of an open, unbounded form, the host perceives the totality of exposure rather than a single manageable piece. The visual design must create discrete psychological containers — each step a room with walls, not a corridor that reveals the distance ahead.
elements.solution: Each wizard step renders inside a single surface card (surface: #ffffff) with radius-lg (16px) and shadow-md, centered on the bg (#f6f4f0) canvas. The card fills no more than 600px wide and is vertically compact — the host should see the step title, all fields, and the action button without scrolling. The progress indicator sits above the card as a thin horizontal track using border (#e2dfd9) for incomplete steps and accent (#2d5a3d) for completed steps. The current step uses a slightly larger dot with accent-bright (#3a7a52). The area outside the card remains empty bg — a visual moat that separates this step from everything else.
elements.contrast_requirements: Step title (ink #1a1714 on surface #ffffff) = 15.2:1, exceeds WCAG AAA. Subtitle (ink-soft #4a4640 on surface #ffffff) = 8.1:1, exceeds AAA. Field labels (ink-muted #8a857e on surface #ffffff) = 3.7:1, meets AA for large text — acceptable for labels paired with high-contrast input values. Button (surface #ffffff on accent #2d5a3d) = 7.4:1, exceeds AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Step title is the only serif element on the card — it anchors attention as the name of 'what you are doing right now,' grounding the host in the manageable present. All other text is Outfit sans-serif at lower weights, creating clear subordination. The action button is the only element using accent fill color, making it the gravitational endpoint of the scan path. No competing colors, no decorative elements within the card — visual austerity mirrors the psychological need for simplicity during self-exposure.
elements.brand_alignment: The surface-on-bg card pattern is the core Split Lease composition: warm, contained, grounded. The bg (#f6f4f0) warmth prevents the clinical feel of white-on-white, which could trigger institutional anxiety. The accent green (#2d5a3d) in progress indicators and buttons is read as growth and safety — a visual counter to the existential exposure the wizard demands. Instrument Serif for titles provides the gravitas of authority without the coldness of sans-serif — the platform speaking as a trustworthy guide, not a bureaucratic form.

evidence.quote: He doesn't bite the world off in one piece as a giant would, but in small manageable pieces, as a beaver does.
evidence.insight: The contained card design is the visual expression of beaver-sized pieces — bounded, finite, separate from the overwhelming whole.

evidence.quote: Completion percentage is a good host nudge... A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish — without being in the way.
evidence.insight: The progress indicator must be visually present but subdued — a thin track above the card, not a dominant element that reminds the host how much remains.

elements.title: Proposal Vetting Card: Trust-Signal Visual Weight
elements.problem: When a proposal arrives, the host scans for threat signals with the urgency of what Becker calls 'the instinct of self-preservation.' If trust signals (verification badge, review score, stay count) are visually equal to neutral information (dates, schedule), the host cannot perform the rapid threat assessment their anxiety demands. The visual hierarchy must make trustworthiness the loudest signal.
elements.solution: The proposal view opens with a guest identity header: circular avatar (48px, radius-full) with a green verification badge overlay (accent #2d5a3d, 16px circle with checkmark) at the bottom-right. Beside the avatar: guest name in Instrument Serif 20px (ink #1a1714), and below it a trust metrics row — review score (accent-bright #3a7a52, Outfit semibold), stay count (ink-soft #4a4640), and 'Verified ID' badge (accent-light #e8f0eb background, accent #2d5a3d text, radius-full pill). This identity block occupies the top 80px and is separated from proposal terms by a border (#e2dfd9) divider. Proposal terms below use a structured grid with ink-muted labels and ink-soft values — deliberately lower visual weight than the identity header.
elements.contrast_requirements: Guest name (ink #1a1714 on surface #ffffff) = 15.2:1, WCAG AAA. Review score (accent-bright #3a7a52 on surface #ffffff) = 4.8:1, meets AA. Verified badge (accent #2d5a3d on accent-light #e8f0eb) = 5.9:1, exceeds AA. Decline text (signal-danger #b83a3a on surface #ffffff) = 5.3:1, meets AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The guest identity header must carry 60% of the visual weight of the entire proposal view. The verification badge is the single most important visual signal — it is the platform's guarantee that the stranger has been vetted, functioning as what Becker calls 'delegated powers.' Proposal terms use a subdued, structured grid — the host processes these as secondary data once trust has been established. Action buttons use a three-level visual weight system: Accept (filled green, maximum prominence), Counter (outlined green, medium), Decline (text-only red, minimum). This hierarchy nudges toward the action that sustains the marketplace while preserving the host's sense of choice.
elements.brand_alignment: The accent green (#2d5a3d) does triple duty: verification badge, review score, Accept button — creating a visual throughline of 'trust verified, proceed safely.' This leverages the warm green as the color of the platform's protective superego. The warm bg and surface palette prevents the proposal from reading as a cold legal document — it reads as a personal introduction mediated by a caring system.

evidence.quote: When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling.
evidence.insight: The visual design must make the guest's reputation the loudest signal — larger type, brand color, premium position. Reputation is the visual character armor the host borrows.

evidence.quote: The fear of death is to be regarded as an analogue of the fear of castration, and the situation to which the ego reacts is the state of being forsaken or deserted by the protecting superego.
evidence.insight: The verification badge is the platform-as-superego made visible. Its visual prominence communicates: we have vetted this person for you — you are not forsaken.

elements.title: Dashboard Urgency Card Traffic-Light System
elements.problem: During active lease, the host's self-preservation instinct requires immediate visual differentiation between what is urgent (overdue actions, potential threats) and what is routine (upcoming events, informational updates). A visually homogeneous dashboard fails to serve the threat-scanning behavior that Becker identifies as 'constant psychological effort to keep the lid on.'
elements.solution: Urgency cards use a left-border accent system: 3px left border in signal-danger (#b83a3a) for overdue items, signal-warn (#c17a28) for due-today items, and accent (#2d5a3d) for upcoming items. Card backgrounds shift subtly: signal-danger-bg (#fde8e8) for overdue, signal-warn-bg (#fef3e2) for today, surface (#ffffff) for upcoming. Each card contains: a status icon (16px, matching border color), a single-line action label (Outfit 15px, ink #1a1714), a time indicator (Outfit 13px, ink-muted #8a857e), and the guest name (Outfit 13px, ink-soft #4a4640). Cards stack vertically with spacing-sm (8px) between them.
elements.contrast_requirements: Action label (ink #1a1714 on signal-danger-bg #fde8e8) = 13.4:1, WCAG AAA. Action label (ink #1a1714 on signal-warn-bg #fef3e2) = 14.0:1, AAA. Overdue border (signal-danger #b83a3a on signal-danger-bg #fde8e8) = 4.2:1, meets AA — the border is decorative but still accessible. Today border (signal-warn #c17a28 on signal-warn-bg #fef3e2) = 3.6:1, meets AA for non-text elements.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Overdue cards must be visually 'hotter' than today cards, which must be 'warmer' than upcoming cards. This is achieved through the three-tier color temperature system: red (hot/danger) -> amber (warm/attention) -> green (cool/safe). The host's eye is drawn to the hottest card first — this is self-preservation made chromatic. The reassurance zone below uses only surface and bg colors — a visual cool-down that signals 'everything below this line is going well.'
elements.brand_alignment: The traffic-light system extends the design system's signal colors into a coherent urgency language. By reserving signal-danger for genuinely overdue items and using the brand accent green for upcoming (safe) items, the dashboard communicates that the platform is monitoring alongside the host. The warm bg canvas behind the card stack prevents the urgency system from feeling alarmist — the cards are embedded in the platform's characteristic warmth, maintaining the vital lie that hosting is fundamentally safe even when specific actions are needed.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings — that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: The visual urgency hierarchy must match the host's psychological urgency hierarchy — what threatens the hero system most gets the most alarming visual treatment.

evidence.quote: We know very well that to repress means more than to put away and to forget... It means also to maintain a constant psychological effort to keep the lid on and inwardly never relax our watchfulness.
evidence.insight: The traffic-light system externalizes the host's watchfulness into color — the host does not need to scan prose to know what requires attention; the color speaks directly to the threat-assessment system.

elements.title: Pricing Default as Confident Visual Anchor
elements.problem: At the pricing step, the host confronts the most acute self-valuation anxiety in the journey. If the default price is presented tentatively — small type, surrounded by options, competing with adjustment controls — the host reads it as uncertain, which amplifies their own uncertainty. The visual treatment must project the confidence the host cannot generate themselves.
elements.solution: The recommended price is displayed as a hero number: Instrument Serif, 48px, ink (#1a1714), centered on the surface card. Below it, a single trust line in Outfit 14px ink-muted (#8a857e): 'Based on 12 similar rooms in [neighborhood].' Below that, the guaranteed income projection in Outfit 18px accent (#2d5a3d): '$X,XXX/month guaranteed.' The market range bar sits beneath, rendered as a thin horizontal track (4px height) using bg-deep (#eae7e1) for the full range and accent (#2d5a3d) for the recommended zone, with the default marked by a small circle (8px). The Accept button (accent bg, surface text, full card width) sits at the bottom. The Adjust link is below the button in ink-muted — present but visually subordinate.
elements.contrast_requirements: Price number (ink #1a1714 on surface #ffffff) = 15.2:1, WCAG AAA. Guaranteed income (accent #2d5a3d on surface #ffffff) = 7.4:1, exceeds AAA. Trust line (ink-muted #8a857e on surface #ffffff) = 3.7:1, meets AA for large text — acceptable as supplementary information. Accept button (surface #ffffff on accent #2d5a3d) = 7.4:1, exceeds AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The price number is the undisputed dominant element — 48px serif type is approximately 3x the size of any other text on the card. This dominance communicates certainty: the platform has decided, and its decision is emphatic. The guaranteed income in accent green creates a secondary anchor that ties the price to the host's primary anxiety buffer (reliable income). The market range bar provides tertiary context — it is thin and subtle because the host should not feel compelled to explore alternatives. The visual message is: here is your price (certainty), here is what it means for you (security), here is where it sits (context).
elements.brand_alignment: Using Instrument Serif at maximum size for the price number leverages the typeface's association with editorial authority — the platform is not asking a question but making a statement. The accent green for guaranteed income reinforces the brand's trust-and-growth color language. The overall composition — serif hero number on a warm surface card — reads as a confident recommendation from a knowledgeable advisor, not as a form field waiting to be filled.

evidence.quote: We don't want to admit that we do not stand alone, that we always rely on something that transcends us, some system of ideas and powers in which we are embedded and which support us.
evidence.insight: The large, confident price number IS the transcendent system. Its visual dominance says: you do not need to stand alone with this decision. Accept the power the platform offers.
The price number (value) is the largest, first element. The Adjust link (the ask to make a decision) is the smallest, last element. Visual size enacts the value-before-ask principle.

elements.title: Cleaning Photo Review as Ritual Restoration Visual
elements.problem: Cleaning photos are proof that the host's sanctuary survived contact with the stranger's 'organismic appetites.' If these photos are presented in a generic media gallery — small thumbnails, no context, utilitarian layout — they fail to serve their ritual function. The host needs to see and confirm that order has been restored; the visual treatment must make this verification feel ceremonial and conclusive.
elements.solution: The cleaning photo review renders as a full-width card on the dashboard with a distinctive visual treatment. Header: 'Cleaning verification from [Guest Name]' in Outfit 16px ink (#1a1714) with a calendar icon and date. Photos display in a 2x2 grid (or 3x2 for more), each at minimum 200px, with radius-sm (6px) and a thin border (#e2dfd9). Below the grid: two full-width action buttons — 'Approve: Space Restored' (accent #2d5a3d bg, surface text) and 'Flag an Issue' (surface bg, signal-warn #c17a28 text, border signal-warn). On approval, the card transitions to a confirmed state: photos dim slightly, a large checkmark overlay appears in accent-light (#e8f0eb), and the text changes to 'Space verified — [date].' This confirmed state remains visible on the dashboard for 48 hours as a reassurance artifact.
elements.contrast_requirements: Header (ink #1a1714 on surface #ffffff) = 15.2:1, WCAG AAA. Approve button (surface #ffffff on accent #2d5a3d) = 7.4:1, exceeds AAA. Flag text (signal-warn #c17a28 on surface #ffffff) = 3.5:1 — supplemented by border treatment for accessibility; icon pairing recommended. Confirmed text (accent #2d5a3d on surface #ffffff) = 7.4:1, exceeds AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Photos are the dominant element — large, full-color, bordered for distinction from the card background. The Approve button is green (safety/restoration confirmed), while the Flag button uses warn amber (concern, not danger). The visual weight of Approve significantly exceeds Flag — the default visual path leads to confirmation that the space is safe. The post-approval confirmed state uses the accent-light green overlay as a visual seal of completion — the ritual is done, the sanctuary is restored.
elements.brand_alignment: The cleaning photo review uses the largest photo treatment anywhere in the host experience — honoring the significance of this ritual moment. The accent-light green overlay on confirmation connects to the brand's growth-and-safety palette, creating a visual moment of relief that closes the anxiety cycle of each stay. The 48-hour persistence of the confirmed state on the dashboard serves as ongoing reassurance — Becker's repression re-engaged through visual proof.

evidence.quote: Repression is not simply a negative force opposing life energies; it lives on life energies and uses them creatively.
evidence.insight: The cleaning photo approval is repression made creative — the host's anxiety about space-invasion is channeled into a positive verification ritual rather than festering as diffuse dread.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard.
evidence.insight: The cleaning photo review card must appear in the urgency stack when pending and transition to the reassurance zone when confirmed — moving from threat-lane to safety-lane mirrors the host's psychological transition.

elements.title: Legacy Summary as Celebratory Narrative Composition
elements.problem: At the retention moment, the host needs visual evidence that their vulnerability was meaningful — that the hosting experience constitutes a legacy, not just a transaction. A standard summary screen (tables, line items, utilitarian layout) fails to provide the narcissistic supply needed to sustain the host's expanded hero system. The visual treatment must feel like a milestone, not a receipt.
elements.solution: The Legacy Summary uses a distinct visual composition unlike any other screen in the host experience. The background shifts from standard bg (#f6f4f0) to a full-bleed accent-light (#e8f0eb) canvas, signaling a special context. The income earned displays as a hero number: Instrument Serif, 56px, ink (#1a1714), centered with generous spacing-xxl (60px) above and below. Below: a three-column metrics row (guests hosted, months provided, average rating) using Instrument Serif 32px ink with Outfit 13px ink-muted labels below each. Review snippets appear in surface (#ffffff) cards with radius-md (10px) and shadow-sm, featuring the guest's avatar, name, and a 2-line excerpt in Outfit italic 15px ink-soft. The re-list CTA uses the standard accent button at full width. The pause option sits below as an ink-muted text link.
elements.contrast_requirements: Hero income (ink #1a1714 on accent-light #e8f0eb) = 12.8:1, WCAG AAA. Metric numbers (ink #1a1714 on accent-light #e8f0eb) = 12.8:1, AAA. Metric labels (ink-muted #8a857e on accent-light #e8f0eb) = 3.2:1, meets AA for large text — acceptable for labels below high-contrast numbers. Review excerpt (ink-soft #4a4640 on surface #ffffff) = 8.1:1, exceeds AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The income number at 56px is the largest typographic element in the entire host experience — it is the platform's declaration that the host's vulnerability had material value. The accent-light canvas differentiates this page from all others, creating a sense of occasion. The three metrics serve as supporting evidence — large enough to read at a glance but subordinate to the income hero. Review snippets provide social validation in intimate, card-based format — each one is a former stranger confirming that the encounter was positive. The overall composition reads top-to-bottom as: what you earned -> what you did -> what they said -> what you can do next.
elements.brand_alignment: The accent-light (#e8f0eb) canvas is used nowhere else in the host experience at full-bleed scale — its deployment here marks the Legacy Summary as a special moment in the brand's visual language. This is the platform celebrating the host, not servicing them. Instrument Serif at maximum scale (56px) combined with the green canvas creates a composition that reads as editorial, almost magazine-like — elevating the host from user to contributor. This celebratory treatment provides the narcissistic supply that Becker identifies as necessary for sustaining the expanded hero system.

evidence.quote: He is driven toward things that support the lie of his character, his automatic equanimity.
evidence.insight: The Legacy Summary is designed to support the lie that hosting is a noble, rewarding, controllable enterprise — providing the visual evidence the host needs to maintain their expanded character structure.

evidence.quote: Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it.
evidence.insight: The visual hierarchy of re-list (prominent button) above pause (subdued link) respects both options while guiding toward continued engagement. Delete is visually absent from this celebratory context.
